div.p: 21. IV:30. At six this morning I left the City of Washington in the Stage for Baltimore. There was already one passenger in the Carriage, and we took up several others at different places. We breakfasted at Kochendorfers at Bladensburg; but it was half past three in the afternoon when we reached the Indian Queen Hotel at Baltimore, now kept by Barnum. It was the heat of the weather which made us so late before we arrived— I dined there and immediately after embarked in the Steam-boat United States Captain Trippe for Frenchtown, which place we reached soon after Midnight— I had no acquaintance on board the vessel, and in the midst of a crowd of fellow-passengers passed the day in solitude— From the moment that I set my foot on board the vessel, the summer heat under which I have been languishing nearly a month at Washington was gone. The weather clouded up, and a strong breeze of wind arose as cool as was to be desired. I betook myself in the evening to a birth.

22.— On landing about one O’Clock this morning at Frenchtown, the Passengers were packed in seven Stages, to Newcastle— I was in Number two with four women, five small children, and one other man— One of the women with two little girls were of the party from Washington. We rode sixteen miles to Newcastle where we arrived just after daylight, about half past four in the morning— We embarked immediately in the Steam-Boat Baltimore, Captain Jenkins and at eight in the morning landed at the wharf in Philadelphia. I left my baggage in the boat and called first upon Samuel Ewing— Then upon Joseph Ingersoll with whom I had some conversation concerning the action of Levett Harris against W. D. Lewis, and the depositions which are to be taken of Mr Crawford and Mr Calhoun— After passing an hour with Ingersoll I returned to Ewing’s, and found at his house R. Peters who told me he had lately returned from Boston and had seen my father and brother at Quincy. Ewing went with me to John Sergeant’s. After a short visit there, I called at the Mansion House Hotel, and at Miss Shinn’s, and enquired if Mr Connell had been there to see me— He had been at Miss Shinn’s, and I immediately afterwards met him in the Street. It was now Noon and I embarked in the Steam-Boat Philadelphia, Captain A. Jenkins for Trenton. Ewing accompanied me to the Boat, and Connell went with us in it as far as Burlington— Miss Sergeant was also a passenger as far as Princeton— Mr Chauncey the lawyer, and a Mr Hall, a relation of Ewing’s came likewise to Burlington— The Boat successively stopped there, at Bristol, and at Bordentown. The river Delaware was so low that the Boat was obliged to stop, at a place which they said was two Miles, but which was nearer five short of Trenton— There the Stages took us up, and we rode first to Trenton then 11 Miles to Princeton, where Miss Sergeant left us, at her Sisters Mrs Millers, and then sixteen Miles to New-Brunswick where we arrived between ten and eleven at Night— We lodge at Mrs Keyworth’s close to the wharf whence the Steam-boat departs. I retired immediately to bed.

23. V: We embarked in the Steam-Boat Bellona Captainfor Powles-Hoek, otherwise called the City of Jersey— For in consequence of a controversy yet unsettled of Jurisdiction between the States of New-York and New-Jersey the Steam-boats of each of those States are prohibited from coming to the shores of the other. From Powles Hoek we crossed in the Steam Ferry-Boat to New-York, and I went to the City Hotel— I immediately called at the Counting House of J. M. Aspinwall number 147. Pearl-Street, and received an order on the United States Branch Bank at Boston, for a dividend of 3 1/2 per Cent on the Estate of Robert Bird, which was declared last June, and of which Mr Aspinwall had given me notice by Letter— At Mr. D. M’Cormick’s I found young Brodie
M’Cormick himself being absent on a tour to Canada— I went to the Post-Office where I found a Letter from my wife at Quincy— On mentioning my name to ask if there were Letters for me, a person who was there on a like errand, turned to me and said that he was not personally acquainted with me, but had heard much of me, and was glad to see me. He told me that he himself was Coll. Loomis and that he had served in our revolutionary war— I next met in the Street Mr Gracie who went with me to Mrs Keene’s 52 Broadway, Mr Jay’s house, where we found Commodore and Mrs Stewart, Mrs Tudor, and Lieutenant Weaver of the Navy. Stewart had received this morning a Letter from the Secretary of the Navy, enclosing an order to J. Q. A. Boyd to join the Franklin, under orders to proceed to the South Sea— I asked Stewart if he could take him, and he promised that he would— He gave me the order from the Navy Department to deliver to him— Mrs Stewart is going upon this expedition with her husband— Stewart asked me, if we could not do something for William Tudor— I said I had a proposal to him from the President, but knew not whether it would suit him— On returning to the City Hotel I found by advertisements in the newspapers that the Steam-ship Robert Fulton, was to depart at five O’Clock this afternoon upon a trip to Newport and Providence, and I immediately determined to take passage in her, instead of waiting till to-morrow morning for the Steam-boat— I accordingly went down to the wharf and engaged my passage after going on board the ship and examining her accommodations. At three O’Clock I dined at the public table at the City Hotel— Called at Coll. Trumbull’s and found him and Mrs Trumbull at dinner— He shewed me the picture which he is now painting for Congress, The surrender of General Burgoyne at Saratoga— I met in the Streets Commodore Chauncey before, and Mr. Wheaton after dinner— At five I embarked in the Steam ship, and half an hour afterwards she left the wharf— The only person whom I knew on board was Mr Van Lennep, whom I had met this morning at Commodore Stewart’s. The weather was as fine as possible: fair and cool. Captain Forman was on board when I embarked, and before leaving the ship introduced to me Mr Dunham the owner— We had a pleasant run down the East-river, through Hell gate, and just at the dusk of Evening passed by Lands’s point into the Sound— The Supper tables were laid under an awning upon the deck, and we had a band of music who from time to time entertained us with enlivening airs— I nevertheless in the midst of this crowd passed the Evening in solitude and about ten O’Clock retired to my birth in one of the State-Rooms.

24. V: Soon after two O’Clock this Morning the ship was abreast of New-Haven, but did not enter the river till after daylight: we came up to the wharf between five and six O’Clock, and left it again at half-past-eight. In the mean time multitudes of people had crowded down to the wharf; great numbers of whom came on board— Among them were Mr and Mrs De Forrest, and Abraham Bishop the Collector— Numbers of people also went out upon the river in sail boats and row-boats to view the ship under weigh— About Noon we passed by the Steam-Boat from New-London bound to New-Haven, with the Corps of Cadets on board, returning from their visit to Boston, with whom a shout of cheers was exchanged as we passed— Our wind had been last Evening, ahead, but it changed this morning, and great part of this day we had the advantage of the sails, additional to the power of Steam— We passed on the outside of Fisher’s Island, came to point Judith about dusk and were along-side of the wharf at Newport Rhode-Island, about nine in the Evening— There we moored for the night— Many of the passengers went ashore for a stroll, and there was a continual stream of the people of the town coming on board as visitors, till after midnight— I had an hour before that time retired to my birth—

25. V: About half an hour after which we departed from Newport, with the cheers of a multitude of people upon the wharf; we proceeded up Providence river, and between ten and eleven, landed upon India wharf at that place— I went immediately to Chapotin’s, and having while on board the ship jogged into a travelling acquaintance with some of my fellow passengers took a stage with five of them for Boston. They were Messrs. Van Lennep, Porter, Hammond, Charles Thorndike, and one other whose name I did not discover. While we were waiting for the Stage I met at Chapotin’s, Mr N. Knight formerly Governor of the State, and now one of its Senators in Congress, who did not at first recognize me; Mr Dexter the Marshal, and Alfred Edwards of Connecticut, just arrived over land from Albany— We dined at Fuller’s at Walpole; and on reaching Gay’s at Dedham, I there found my dear wife, and my Son John, who had come from Quincy to meet me— I then left my fellow travellers of the Steam-ship, and with my wife and son came to my fathers house, where we arrived just at the dusk of Evening— I found at my fathers a very numerous family— My brother and his wife with five children—Abigail, Elizabeth Coombs, Thomas Boylston, John Quincy, and Joseph Harrod, the sixth, Isaac Hull, being at Haverhill, with my brother’s wifes Parents— My own family; my brother Charles’s daughter the widow Susan Boylston Clarke, with her daughter Susan between three and four years old— Louisa C. Smith, Mary Hellen, W. S. Shaw, and J. Q. A. Boyd, lately returned in the Columbus 74 from the Mediterranean were all there, and we made up a company of nineteen persons— My father’s health is not good. He suffers much pain with the Sciatica, and has now a troublesome inflammation of the eyes, which deprives him of the power of reading. My brother has not entirely recovered from bruises received by oversetting ten days since in a Chaise. My Son George is in very infirm health. The rest of the family are well. Commodore Bainbridge, and Mr Brown the Senator from Louisiana had been here this morning.

26. V:30.Mr Ward Nicholas Boylston and his wife were here and passed the day. I attended at meeting, and heard morning and afternoon, Mr Francis of Watertown— He dined with us at my father’s. P. P. F. Degrand came out from Boston, and I strolled with him over the hills. Captain Beale and Mr Quincy with his Son were here in the Evening. My brother continues quite unwell— I had not seen Mr Boylston since I sailed for Russia in 1809. He is rather bowed than broken with his years, and retains much of the vivacity of his Spirits. I attempted this day to write but with little success.

27. VI: There was this morning an eclipse of the Sun of nine or ten digits; and which lasted about three hours—but the sky was beclouded almost the whole time, so that it could be but imperfectly observed— I barely perceived it several times through a smoked fragment of glass— W. S. Shaw and J. Q. A. Boyd went to Boston, and my Son George to Cambridge to prepare for Commencement. Mr John Marston called to see me, and Mr Quincy visited my father with Mr Pomeroy and J. S. Skinner the Postmaster at Baltimore, and Editor of the American farmer. After dinner I took a ride with my father to the farm at Mount Wollaston.

28. V:30. My Son John went to Boston this morning with Mary Hellen and left her at Mr James H. Foster’s—he returned with J. Q. A. Boyd to Quincy before dinner. William Tudor came out with Mrs Langdon Elwyn, and Mrs John Gore to visit my father and my wife. After dinner we came into Boston, and took lodgings at Mrs. Jenks’s in Beacon-Street. There was no room at Mrs Burr’s nor at Mr Jones’s where we had heretofore lodged, nor at the Marlborough Hotel, and new and large establishment, where we visited Mr. W. Patterson, of Baltimore and Mrs R. Patterson his daughter in law. I had scarcely alighted at Mrs Jenks’s, when Mr W. Shaler, the Consul-General to Barbary came in— He arrived yesterday from the Mediterranean, upon a leave of absence for a year, and is going in a few days to New-York. He told me that he had Reports to make upon business relating to his Office, and particularly of an application made to him from the
Agent of the Prussian Agent, to negotiate for peace with Algiers, soliciting the interposition of his good offices for effecting that object. This application was made to him in June last at Marseilles; Shaler declined all formal official interference, but gave the Agent Henry Putter, the best information in his power to enable him to succeed, and a Letter of recommendation to his nephew W. Shaler junr—whom he left at Algiers charged with the Affairs of the Consulate during his absence. Shaler also told me that he should call on me again in two or three days to introduce to me, Mr Folsom, who was his Charge d’Affaires during the time of the plague, and who is a very deserving young man— I spent the Evening at Jos. Hall’s, where I met Dr Bartlett.

29. V:30. Commencement day— I went to Cambridge with Mr W. N. Boylston, who called for me, by agreement made last Sunday. He came at 8 O’Clock, and on reaching Cambridge we went immediately to the College Library Rooms. At ten the procession to the Meeting House was formed, and proceeded as usual. The exercises were shorter than I ever witnessed on a like occasion; and the speaking was in general very indifferent— My eldest son, George Washington Adams was one of those who graduated, and had a part in the second Conference— Of four who should have spoken in that conference; he alone performed. The two English Orations were by Barnwall and Upham, the latter of which was best delivered— There was no poem— No performance in Hebrew or Greek—only one in Latin, the salutatory, and no forensic disputation— There was no exhibition of Theses, nor of Master’s Questions. No Valedictory Oration, and the only performance for the Master’s degree was an English Oration, said to be upon Genius, but so far as I could hear it, upon Love— Spoken in a note barely above a whisper, by Reed— Though sitting close by the side of the Orator, I heard not more than half he said— It appeared to me well written, but full of strange and absurd fancies— He is said to have a Swedénborgian crack in his brain. On the whole the performances, both with reference to classic learning and to ornamental exhibition, were the most indifferent that I ever witnessed on such an occasion. I dined in the Hall— Of my own Classmates, there were present, only three—Jonathan Amory, T. M. Harris and W. Hunnewell— After dinner, the 78th. Psalm was sung to the tune of Old Hundred.— My Son George had a small party to dine, at Smith’s Tavern, where I found Mrs Adams, and my brother’s family— Governor Brooks and his Council, President Kirkland, Mr T. Pickering and some others called there by invitation from me— Thence we went to the President’s where we found a numerous company— About Sunset we returned to Boston. Mr Boylston sat me down, at Mrs Jenks’s, with a promise to call for me again to-morrow morning at 8— We attended in the Evening a Ball at Mr H. G. Otis’s— His son William was also one of the graduates of this day. At Otis’s, I met among the company old Mr de Valnais the French Consul, and his daughter.

30. V:30.Mr Boylston called for me at 8, according to his engagement— Mrs Boylston was with him. We went immediately to President Kirkland’s house at Cambridge— The speaking, for Mr Boylston’s prizes commenced at half past nine. I attended as one of the judges, being made permanently one of them, by the founder. The names of the competitors were given to us, by President Kirkland, with a note of the piece selected by each of them for declamation— There were twelve of the Junior, and seven of the Senior Class, who had entered their names for speaking. No graduates of the year. By the foundation, the competition is limited to those three Classes. There was no settled mode among the judges of marking the comparative merit of the performers; but I adopted that recommended by President Kirkland of marking the name of each speaker immediately after he finished, from 1 to 4. in figures, affixing the highest number to the best, and graduating downwards according to merit. The judges set in the front galleries in the Meeting house, with Mr Boylston the founder in the centre— The junior Class Candidates spoke first, and after them the Seniors. The performances lasted about two hours after which the judges returned to President Kirkland’s study. The
votes for assigning the prizes, were taken by ballot; but there was a want of regulation as to the mode of taking them; and much diversity of opinion with regard to the relative merit of the Speakers. The judges were President Kirkland, Dr Porter of Roxbury, Judge Davis, Chief Justice Parker, Mr John Lowell, Mr John Pickering and Mr Ware, son of the Professor—John Phillips, and myself— I found from the balloting that the persons most defective in their own elocution, differed most from the majority in their opinions. There were two first prizes of 15 dollars each, and three second prizes of 10 dollars. They were all at last allotted as I should have given them, with the exception of one first and one second prize, which I should have substituted for each other— My son John was among the unsuccessful candidates. He spoke with propriety, and without sufficient force and animation— The pieces were all sufficiently committed to memory; but few of them were well chosen— There was no poetry, and no dialogue. Altogether the speaking was poor, for want of elementary instruction in the art of declamation— We had but scanty time for the assignment of the prizes and at twelve went again to the Meeting House, and heard the ΦBK exercises—an Oration by John C. Gray, and a poem in the Spenserian Stanza, Byronized, by a Mr Bryant— Gray’s Oration was well written and well delivered— The Poem was poetical in the thoughts and prosaic in the language— Poetry without numbers, and rhyme without harmony. We dined with a party of more than twenty at President Kirkland’s— Professor Farrar lives with him in the house, and his family, the President being a bachelor. After dinner, with Mr Boylston and professor Cogswell I visited the University library and medical school. Saw the Ebeling library, a present from I. Thorndike, a beautiful manuscript copy of the aphorisms of Hippocrates, presented by Mr Boylston, and the anatomical preparations given by Mr J. Nicholls. I then returned to Boston with Mr. Boylston taking with us my Son John— I promised Mr Boylston to visit him at Princeton the week after next, and to allot the whole week to the visit. Evening spent at a Ball, at Mrs. John Gore’s.

31. VI:15. Received a Letter from D. Brent, chief clerk in the Department of State, with several enclosures. Morning at the Athenaeum— Received visits from Dr. Jarvis, rector of the new Episcopalian Church in this town, and from many other persons; which absorbed all the morning— We dined at our lodgings, and after dinner W. S. Shaw called with a Horse and Chaise, and I went with him to Cambridge, over the new Mill dam avenue. We went to the chamber of my Sons in Massachusetts Hall, and found there my Son Charles who had passed his examination for admission. My wife also came out with Harriet Welsh. There was with Charles, a youth named Elwyn, who had also passed the Examination. I went with Shaw over to Dr Waterhouse’s— In conversation with him, some mention was made of Dr. W. Gordon, author of a History of the American Revolution. I thought he had been a Scotchman; but Waterhouse said he was a native of England; and after returning from this Country to England, had written him several Letters which he would shew me. On returning to the College, I found that Mrs Adams and Harriet Welsh were gone. The boys went down to President Kirkland’s for information as to the issue of their examination, but were directed to come again at nine O’Clock— I returned with Shaw to Boston, and with Mrs Adams called in the Evening at Dr Welsh’s. The Dr himself was at Rainsford’s Island, in the harbour, being the health-Officer of the port. Mrs Welsh was at her son Thomas’s, who has a child dangerously ill— Miss Ann Hinkley a friend of Harriet Welsh’s was with her—and my son John was there.

Day. The first three weeks of the Month, the distribution of my time was much as it had been for many Months before. Excepting that from the opening of the Theatre I constantly frequented it, till I left Washington— In five days I came from that City to Quincy, and since then nothing regular in my occupations. Every day and hour of my life I feel more heavily my incapacity of writing, and in the continual bustle of the present, it nearly disqualifies me for all use of the pen—
